I also get very anxious when I know he’s coming home soon, because I know it is going to be constant critiques. Also, when I ask him if he wants to go someplace with me and the kids, he never wants to and gets upset about it. I get in a bad mood too and he ends up leaving. In which doesn’t make any sense because he said he didn’t want to go anywhere. I have told him how much these things bother me. Every time, he turns around and says what bother him. Nothing gets resolved. I work from home and it’s difficult because I am also watching the kids. He doesn’t like anyone else watching the kids so I try to the majority of the time, unless I have somewhere important to go to. We used to be a lot different. We would go out to dinner, shopping, ext. We would watch TV together and he really didn’t critique me all too much. He used to say good things about me in which he doesn’t say anymore. For example, he used to call me “pretty girl”. He has not said that for awhile now. We have also went through some crap that hurt our relationship. I cannot say I’m overall miserable because I do enjoy spending time with my children. My underneath layer is hurt, badly. I feel like my feelings don’t matter. I don’t know when and if to call it quits. We have been married for 6 years and I don’t give up easily. I do love him but I wish he was how he was when we got married. He actually cared and SHOWED me how much he loved me.
Response:
Cognitive Distortion: Emotional Reasoning -- Believing “I feel that way, so it must be true”

The patient's narrative is heavily influenced by their emotional state, with a focus on the negative feelings they experience when interacting with their husband. They repeatedly express how his behavior makes them feel anxious, miserable, and hurt, without critically evaluating whether these emotions are based on objective facts or if there might be other explanations for his behavior. The patient's reliance on their emotional experiences to define reality is characteristic of Emotional Reasoning.

I was honest and answered truthfully. He then began pulling away…saying I purposefully kept this from him. We broke up and got back together 3 times. Anytime he asks about it, I answer truthfully again. I have nothing to hide. Each time we have gotten back together, it has been better, but not anywhere near where it should be. He still believes I purposefully withheld this information, when in reality, I had never dated anyone that really cared about my past, so I didn’t think to share it. This situation has been a wall between us since we got together. I have done everything I know to do to reassure him and to help reestablish trust. This morning he tells me I haven’t done anything to make him believe in me. I feel like I have been busting my hump (so to speak), but at this point I don’t know what to do. Please help…how can I prove that I was telling the truth those months ago so we can be the couple we are more than capable of being?
Response:
Cognitive Distortion: Personalization

The distortion is evident in your statement "I have done everything I know to do to reassure him and to help reestablish trust." This suggests that you're taking responsibility for his lack of trust, implying that it's solely up to you to fix the situation. However, his behavior and reactions are beyond your control. You've already been honest with him about your past, and he still chooses not to believe you. It's essential to recognize that his actions and attitudes are a reflection of himself, rather than something you can "fix" or change through your efforts alone.

In CBT, we would work on reframing this thought pattern by acknowledging that you've done what you can to communicate openly and honestly with him, but ultimately, it's up to him to decide how he feels about the situation. This might involve exploring ways for you to take care of yourself and prioritize your own emotional well-being in the face of his continued skepticism.

Cognitive Distortion: Overgeneralization, All-or-Nothing Thinking, Emotional Reasoning, Fortune-telling, Magnification, Personalization, Labeling

Anecdote:

The client's narrative is replete with examples of cognitive distortions. Here are some specific instances:

* "I always get overwhelmed with the tiniest bit of stress" (Overgeneralization) - This statement implies that the client experiences extreme distress in response to minor stressors.
* "I have a horrible habit... I have also called in sick to avoid uni or exams" (All-or-Nothing Thinking) - The client's tendency to label themselves as having a "horrible habit" and their decision to call in sick due to anxiety suggest an absolute, rather than nuanced, perspective on their behavior.
* "The very moment that I wake up I start talking, imagining situations... which might never arise or practice what to say at uni today" (Emotional Reasoning) - The client's self-talk and rumination about hypothetical scenarios may be driven by emotional reasoning, where they assume the worst-case scenario is likely to occur.
* "I sometimes feel that my dad will go bankrupt because of me" (Fortune-telling) - This statement suggests that the client predicts a catastrophic outcome based on their own perceived shortcomings.
* "I have become very rude to my family but cry to myself when I do that" (Magnification) - The client's tendency to catastrophize their behavior and its consequences is evident in this statement.
* "Sometimes I am in an excited mood and say/do things without thinking and then regret. else I am awfully depressed" (Personalization) - The client takes responsibility for events beyond their control, such as their emotional state.
* "I look at myself in the mirror and mainly notice the flaws in myself and cry about how I used to be pretty and look horrible now" (Labeling) - This statement illustrates the client's tendency to label themselves negatively.

It is essential to note that these distortions may contribute to the client's feelings of hopelessness, self-doubt, and anxiety. A thorough assessment and exploration of these cognitive patterns can help identify areas for intervention in therapy.

I feel bad about my fiancé how I talk to her but my mind just nonstop thinking crazy stuff:( I’m really at my end with what to do. She love of my life but I feel I should make her leave me so I don’t ruin her life. I’m really scared :(
Response:
Cognitive Distortion: Emotional Reasoning, Overgeneralization, Mental Filter, Should Statements, All-or-Nothing Thinking, Mind Reading, Fortune-telling, Magnification, Personalization, Labeling

Here's a breakdown of the distortions present in the anecdote:

* Emotional Reasoning: "I feel I'm ugly and no girl could possibly love me so they must have another guy." (Believing one's feelings are facts)
* Overgeneralization: "I never know what to say to people at dinners or anything so I have panic attacks. I feel like all my friends want my girlfriend like they only around to get her." (Drawing sweeping negative conclusions with limited instances)
* Mental Filter: Focusing on the negative aspects of social interactions and relationships, while ignoring the positive ones.
* Should Statements: "I should make her leave me so I don't ruin her life." (Expecting a certain outcome or behavior)
* All-or-Nothing Thinking: Believing that one's flaws are insurmountable and that it's hopeless. ("I have so many things wrong I feel it's hopeless.")
* Mind Reading: "They were looking at me weird like they can tell I'm off and weird" (Concluding that others are reacting negatively to you, without any basis in fact)
* Fortune-telling: "I thought her friends plotting against me." (Predicting a negative outcome without evidence)
* Magnification: Exaggerating the severity of one's flaws and shortcomings. ("I have so many things wrong I feel it's hopeless.")
* Personalization: Holding oneself personally responsible for events beyond one's control, such as the actions of others. ("I'm ruining her life")
* Labeling: Attaching negative labels to oneself (e.g., "ugly", "off and weird")
